subject: Re: SV: [junit] Where to place test classes?
msgSnippet: Are you open to the possibility that your Tool class might need to collaborate with other objects (with their own public methods) to do its job or are you
messageBody:
Are you open to the possibility that your Tool class might need to
collaborate with other objects (with their own public methods) to do
its job or are you married to the notion that private methods need
tests?



>>>>> "jon-s" == jon-s bratseth <jon-s.bratseth@...> writes:

jon-s> Consider this counter example i encountered recently when
jon-s> making a tool for unit testing store procedures.

jon-s> The tool reads a file containing a test specification, and
jon-s> then executes the test. Thus the only public methods I want
jon-s> to see is read(file) and execute() throws
jon-s> TestFailException.

jon-s> Now, do you think that a sufficient test is to supply some
jon-s> working and non-working test spec examples a see if the
jon-s> right ones fail? Of course not.

jon-s> In fact, such examples are common in applications which
jon-s> contain more complex functionality than data shuffling, and
jon-s> the notion than testing public methods is sufficient is
jon-s> just plain wrong. Consider simulators, rule engines,
jon-s> planners etc.

jon-s> Btw, I don't like to have my unit tests in the same
jon-s> package, but I don't like the alternative either. What we
jon-s> need is a friend construct. Tests commonly needs a backdoor
jon-s> to classes, and so does parsistence layers. There is a
jon-s> diference between the system level and business level
jon-s> interface of classes.

jon-s> -- Jon S Bratseth, Zenior AS

>> -----Opprinnelig melding----- Fra: Miles, Eric SAXONHQ
>> [mailto:milese@...] Sendt: 14. mars 2002 23:35 Til:
>> 'junit@yahoogroups.com' Emne: RE: [junit] Where to place test
>> classes?
>>
>>
>> I'd have to agree with Mr. Rainsberger. I see no need to test
>> methods other than public. My reasoning is public method types
>> are what's exposed to the public, therefore, test them well.
>> If the class is primary used via inheritance, I'll write test
>> methods for the protected methods as well. Otherwise, I don't
>> bother with private method types. They're indirectly tested
>> through the methods they support.
>>
>>
>> -----Original Message----- From: J. B. Rainsberger
>> [mailto:jbr@...] Sent: Thursday, March 14, 2002
>> 5:20 PM To: junit@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [junit] Where to
>> place test classes?
>>
>>
>> >Another purpose for using JUnit is to create tests >first and
>> then write code. For those that take this >approach to
>> development, they would probably want a >test for each method.
>>
>> I'm sorry to be blunt, but absolutely not.
>>
>> In TFP, the goal is to test every feature -- that is, every bit
>> of behavior you care about. Implementation details are
>> unimportant and, in fact, testing
>>
>> them on their own often impedes refactoring. Since tests are
>> meant to provide the "safety net" during refactoring, they
>> should try not to get in the way of refactoring, if they can
>> avoid it.
>>
>> If you have one feature that uses four or five private methods
>> behind a single public method, then it's best simply to test
>> the public method. If you find a bug in there, then that may be
>> a clue about your design: perhaps what you perceive as an
>> implementation detail is something bigger that should be in its
>> own class. At that point, the method becomes public and voila,
>> you can test it. (Or package-level, if you prefer that route
>> and place your tests in the same package as the production
>> code.)
>>
>> "A test for each method" is a bad thing. "Tests for each
>> feature or service"
>>
>> is a Good Thing.
>>
